raw_text:
Balco case trial date pushed back
 
 The trial date for the Bay Area Laboratory Cooperative (Balco) steroid distribution case has been postponed.
 
 US judge Susan Illston pushed back a preliminary evidentiary hearing - which was due to take place on Wednesday - until 6 June. No official trial date has been set but it is expected to begin in September. Balco founder Victor Conte along with James Valente, coach Remy Korchemny and trainer Greg Anderson are charged with distributing steroids to athletes.
 
 Anderson's clients include Barry Bonds, and several other baseball stars have been asked to appear before a congressional inquiry into steroid use in the major leagues. The Balco defence team have already lost their appeal to have the case dismissed at a pre-trial hearing in San Francisco but will still argue the case should not go to trial. The hearing in June will focus on the admissibility of evidence gathered during police raids on Balco's offices and Anderson's home. Conte and Anderson were not arrested at that point but federal agents did obtain statements from them. The defence are expected to challenge the legality of those interviews and if Ilston agrees she could could reject all the evidence from the raids. Balco has been accused by the United States Anti-Doping Agency (USADA) of being the source of the banned steroid THG and modafinil.
 
 Former double world champion Kelli White and Olympic relay star Alvin Harrison have both been banned on the basis of materials discovered during the Balco investigation. Britain's former European 100m champion Dwain Chambers is currently serving a two-year ban after testing positive for THG in an out-of-competition test in 2003. And American sprinter Marion Jones has filed a lawsuit for defamation against Conte following his allegations that he gave her performance-enhancing drugs.
llama3.2:1b: The trial date for the Balco case has been postponed due to a preliminary evidentiary hearing scheduled for June 6, which is now expected to start in September. The defense team will argue against going to trial. Former clients of Balco founder Victor Conte and coach Remy Korchemny are expected to testify about police raids on their offices and home.

The defense will challenge the legality of statements gathered during police raids on Balco's offices and Anderson's home, which could affect the admissibility of evidence.

The defence team has already lost their appeal against dismissal but will still challenge the admissibility of evidence from police raids on Balco's offices and Anderson's home. Evidence gathered includes statements taken from Conte and Anderson without arrest; the defence is expected to contest their legality. USADA accuses Balco of being a source of banned steroids THG and modafinil. Several athletes, including Kelli White and Alvin Harrison, have been banned based on materials from this investigation. Dwain Chambers serves a ban for positive THG test in 2003, while Marion Jones has filed defamation lawsuit against Conte over allegations of performance-enhancing drugs.

tinyllama:1.1b: The Balco steroid distribution case has been postponed due to a change in trial date. The preliminary evidentiary hearing, which was scheduled for this week, will now take place on June 6th instead of Wednesday as originally planned. The reason for the delay is that US judge Susan Illston pushed back the hearing until September to allow Balco founder Victor Conte and his co-defendants James Valentine, coach Remy Korchemny, and sports trainer Greg Anderson the opportunity to appeal their case in court. They have already lost their appeal at a pretrial hearing in San Francisco but will now argue that none of the evidence gathered during police raids on Balco's offices and Anderson's home should be admitted into the case. In addition, former double world champion Kelli White and Olympic relay star Alvin Harrison were also banned by USAADA based on materials discovered during the investigation. And American sprinter Marion Jones filed a lawsuit against Conte for defamation after he accused him of giving him performance-enhancing drugs.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Balco, a laboratory cooperative located in the Bay Area, was scheduled to commence its trial on June 6th. However, an extension of the preliminary evidentiary hearing has been granted, pushing back the actual date of the trial until September 6th. The main charges against Victor Conte, James Valente, and Remy Korchemny involve the distribution of performance-enhancing substances to athletes in the major leagues. Balco founder, Victor Conte, and other defendants, including Barry Bonds and several other baseball stars, have been subpoenaed by a congressional inquiry into steroid use in professional sports. The hearing in June is focused on admissibility of evidence gathered during police raids on Balco's offices and Anderson's home. Conte and Anderson have not been officially arrested but federal agents obtained statements from them. The defense team is expected to challenge the legality of these interviews and if Judge Susan Illston agrees, she could reject all the evidence collected during these raids. Balco has been accused by USADA of being the source of the banned substances THG and modafinil.

granite3.1-dense:2b:
The trial date for the Balco steroid distribution case, involving founder Victor Conte, coach Remy Korchemny (who trains Barry Bonds and other baseball stars), trainer Greg Anderson, and James Valente, has been delayed until at least September. Initially set to begin in June, the preliminary evidentiary hearing was postponed by US Judge Susan Illston on Wednesday. The defence aims to challenge the legality of evidence obtained during police raids on Balco's offices and Anderson's home, which could potentially exclude crucial proof against the accused.

Balco is charged with distributing performance-enhancing drugs, specifically THG and modafinil, according to the US Anti-Doping Agency (USADA). This includes former double world champion Kelli White, Olympic relay star Alvin Harrison, and British athlete Dwain Chambers, who is currently serving a two-year ban. American sprinter Marion Jones has also sued Conte for defamation following his allegations of drug use. A congressional inquiry into steroid use in the major leagues has asked several baseball stars to testify, including Anderson's clients.

The defense team has already lost an appeal to dismiss the case but will argue against proceeding to trial. The June hearing will determine the admissibility of evidence from police raids on Balco's offices and Anderson's home, which the defense may challenge. Balco has been accused by USADA of supplying banned substances THG and modafinil. Several athletes, including Kelli White, Alvin Harrison, and Dwain Chambers, have been banned due to the investigation, while Marion Jones has sued Conte for defamation over his doping allegations.
